channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Markets Tumble as Ukraine Crisis Deepens
item.description: As tension between Moscow and Kiev escalated, the crisis appeared to unsettle investors who had already been nervous about shaky emerging market economies.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: The scene outside a Moscow currency exchange on Monday. As tensions grew in Ukraine, the ruble fell to a record low against the dollar.

item.title: At U.N., Russia Points to Ultranationalist Threats in Ukraine
item.description: Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, said his country’s troops were in Ukraine to protect ethnic Russians from attacks.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:credit: Salvatore Di Nolfi/KEYSTONE, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Sergey V. Lavrov, the Russian foreign minister, spoke Monday before the United Nations Human Rights Council in Geneva.

item.title: The Lede: March 1 Updates on Ukraine Crisis
item.description: The Lede is following events in Ukraine and Russia on Saturday, following a unanimous vote in the upper house of the Russian Parliament approving a request from President Vladimir Putin to send a military force to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: World Leaders Warn Kremlin as Ukraine Standoff Continues
item.description: Amid anxiety about Russian aims in eastern Ukraine, the British foreign secretary visited Kiev on Monday and warned of “significant costs” for Russia, echoing other leaders’ stern words.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Report People From Xinjiang, Police Say After Deadly Attack
item.description: A police station in the southern region of Guangxi has called on citizens to report any people from Xinjiang in their midst, after attackers believed to be from the far western region killed at least 29 people on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A sign in the airport in Guangzhou, Guangdong Province, reading "Urumqi: Special Security Channel," alerts travelers heading for the capital of Xinjiang that they have to proceed through a separate security line.

item.title: South African Athlete Pleads Not Guilty to Murder Charge
item.description: At the murder trial of Oscar Pistorius, the double amputee track star, a witness described “bloodcurdling screams” on the night of the killing.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius arrived in court on Monday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Video Said to Be of Kunming Knife Attack Appears Online
item.description: Video has emerged on a Chinese video-sharing service that apparently shows scenes from the knife attack in the Kunming train station on Saturday that left at least 29 people dead.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Hong Kong Businessman Found Guilty of Money Laundering
item.description: Carson Yeung, the owner of the Birmingham City soccer club, faces a maximum of seven years in jail for five counts in the laundering of a total of nearly $100 million.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL GOUGH

item.title: War Death Toll for Afghan Security Forces Is Over 13,000
item.description: The figures suggest that many more Afghan soldiers and police officers have been killed during the war than previously thought.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Suicide Bombers Kill 11 in Pakistani Capital
item.description: A group of armed men, including two suicide attackers, stormed a court complex in the Pakistani capital on Monday in a rare terror attack in the heart of Islamabad that killed 11 people and wounded dozens.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: 11 Killed in Suicide Attack on Court in Pakistan’s Capital
item.description: A senior judge was among those killed in the attack on the district court complex in Islamabad.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: U.N. Security Council Condemns ‘Terrorist Attack’ in Kunming
item.description: As the United Nations Security Council condemned the attack in China’s Kunming train station that left at least 29 dead, the authorities moved to delete social media posts that called on leaders to allow open discussion of the situation in Xinjiang, where tensions are running high.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A police officer standing guard as mourners lighted candles at the scene of the attack at the main train station in Kunming.

item.title: North Korean Officials Expel Elderly Australian Evangelist
item.description: The missionary, John Short, had asked for leniency after he was accused of secretly distributing Christian materials while visiting a Buddhist temple in Pyongyang.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: The Lede: Ukrainian Activists Work to Counter Russian Narrative on Social Networks
item.description: Faced with what they call misleading reports on Russian state television that ethnic-nationalist violence is sweeping Ukraine, Internet-savvy Ukrainian activists drew attention on Sunday to social media images to counter that narrative.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Deadly Attacks Tied to Islamist Militants Shake Nigeria
item.description: The Islamist group Boko Haram was blamed for the attacks, which killed dozens, including many children watching a soccer match.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Nigerians gathered around a crater created by a car bombing in Maiduguri, where a series of blasts on Saturday killed dozens.

item.title: In Crimea’s Phantom War, Armed Men Face Unseen Foe
item.description: Heavily armed men come and go in Crimea to confront an enemy nobody has actually seen, except in imaginations agitated by Russian television.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Unidentified armed men outside a Ukrainian military base in the village of Perevalnoye, in Crimea. Masks and uniforms of soldiers are mostly shorn of markings.

item.title: High-Interest Web Banks on the Rise in China
item.description: The sector’s growth is intensifying competition for deposits and putting pressure on state-run banks, which are struggling with a severe cash squeeze.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA
item.media:description: Jack Ma, the founder of Alibaba, says regulations are stifling investment and savers.

item.title: Frustrated With the Pace of Change, Rioters Storm Parliament Building in Libya
item.description: Less than two weeks after a vote to elect an assembly, hopes of renewed momentum to create a constitution were dampened after the violent attack.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Action by Russia Divides Immigrants in New York
item.description: The confrontation between Russia and Ukraine reverberated through New York City’s tight-knit ethnic enclaves, where protesters shouted their opposition to Russia’s military involvement in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By J. DAVID GOODMAN
item.media:description: Demonstrators converged across from the Russian consulate in Manhattan to protest the country’s military action in Ukraine.

item.title: Pressure Rising as Obama Works to Rein In Russia
item.description: President Obama rallied allies and approved a series of diplomatic and economic moves intended to isolate Moscow and prevent it from seizing more Ukrainian territory.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: President Obama on Friday. On Sunday, he spoke with allies about Crimea and sent Secretary of State John Kerry to Ukraine.

item.title: Putin Engages in Test of Will Over Ukraine
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has pursued his strategy with subterfuge, propaganda and brazen military threat, taking aim as much at the United States and Europe as Ukraine itself.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers on Sunday guarded the entrance to the Ukrainian military base in the village of Perevalnoye, in Crimea.

item.title: Kerry Plans to Visit Ukraine in Show of Support and Warns Russia of Penalties
item.description: The United States says Russia risks eviction from the Group of 8 and that assets of Russian businesses could be frozen if the Kremlin does not reverse its occupation of Crimea.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Ukrainian Government Rushes to Dampen Secessionist Sentiment
item.description: With Russia in control of Crimea, worries mounted in Kiev that the mostly ethnic-Russian east could be next to fall.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-Russian protesters gathered in the eastern city of Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Sunday. Many said they would even prefer that Russian troops invade the city instead of submitting to Kiev’s rule.

item.title: Ultra-Orthodox Jews Clog Jerusalem Streets to Protest a Draft Bill
item.description: Demonstrators railed against a government plan that could conscript yeshiva students and holds the threat of arrest for those who dodge the draft.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Hundreds of thousands of ultra-Orthodox Jews held a rally Sunday to express opposition to a proposed draft law.

item.title: The Media Equation: Foreign Buyers Eyeing Forbes Magazine, a Chronicler of the World’s Wealthiest
item.description: All good things come to an end, even for the rich, and sometime this month, Forbes will probably pass out of family control and into the hands of a foreign owner.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID CARR
item.media:description: Steve Forbes, speaking at a news conference in 2011, spent close to $70 million running for president twice.
